transcripts.text: Chinese Communist Party members in Chinese divisions of major U.S.  corporations, hundreds of them are on a leaked database.  A Chinese lawyer fighting for human rights is detained for two months.  His family members become targets of the communist regime, including his elderly parents.  Another virus broke out in China under suspect circumstances.  There are no human to human transmission cases reported.  China retaliates to Australia and bans many goods from the country, but it cannot ban one thing that it desperately needs.  And communist officials allegedly attacked U.S.  diplomats and its own citizens with a new form of weapon that targets their brains.  Welcome to China In Focus.  I'm Tiffany Meyer.  Hundreds of Chinese Communist Party members are embedded in Chinese divisions of major U.S.  corporations.  That's according to a leaked CCP member database.  NTD's Patrick Hayden reports.

A leaked CCP member database shows that major U.S.  firms like IBM, PepsiCo and 3M house Chinese Communist Party units in China.  The nearly two million member list uncovers the scale of the CCP's influence on international companies.  China analyst Bill Gertz told American thought leaders the CCP is like a mafia kind of system.

They can use information that they gain from inside of companies or inside of foreign governments, and they know how to put all of this together.  It's not disparate pieces of information.  They have major plans in place.
He says CCP members are devoted to the Communist Party, not to the nation of China.
Yeah, it's not just a political party.  It's an ideological drive, as I say in my book, to basically take over the world.

The list shows that IBM has over 800 CCP members and at least 24 party branches.  3M has 230 members and five party units, while PepsiCo has 45 members in its unit.  The Chinese regime requires any organization with at least three CCP members to form a party branch, and state media says 70% of foreign businesses in China have a party unit.  China currently has about 92 million CCP members.  Goertz says while the leak only represents a small number of the total members, it's a key piece in the puzzle because it lists names and party branches, and now we can start unraveling some of the CCP's networks.  Reporting by Patrick Hayden, NTD News.

A human rights lawyer in China has been arrested for his efforts of helping people who had been treated unfairly by authorities.  Now his family members are being harassed by police.  Even their careers are at risk.  NTD's Xiong Bing reports.

For two months, human rights lawyer Chang Weiping in northwest Chinese Shaanxi Province has been detained.  The authorities said it was for inciting subversion of state power.  His family members continually spoke out for him.  As a result, they were threatened and monitored by police.  Since last week, Chang's parents were summoned several times for, quote, provoking trouble.  This was after they held up a display board outside the police station demanding the release of their son.  Last week, a high-definition camera was installed on the door opposite to Chang's parents' home.  The police stay around and come out to threaten anyone who visits the elderly couple.  The director of the police station has repeatedly threatened to detain Chang's wife or limit her freedoms.  The mobile phones of Chang's parents, eldest brother-in-law and father-in-law were all taken away.  So they are unable to communicate with the outside world.  One of Chang's sisters and brother-in-law are teachers.  They were summoned several times last week by the county education bureau.  His brother-in-law was arranged by the education bureau to stay at his parents' home all day and was forced to report Chong's parents' every activity to the authorities.  Chong's eldest sister's family was also warned not to support him.  They were told.  if they did, their son would not be accepted by any colleges, nor be qualified to be a government official later.  Since all communication paths were cut off, no one knows what is going on with the case so far.  Chang mainly represented public interest litigation cases.  The defendants were often authorities or companies with ties to authorities.  Chang's friend from the legal profession, Mr.  Zhang, criticized the Bar Association for not defending Chang's rights.  To protect his identity, we only use his surname.

This is an obligation clearly stipulated in the constitution of the Bar Association.  The association charges membership fees, but never defends its members.  On the contrary, it helps to persecute its members.  The Department of Justice and the Bar Association work together to persecute the lawyers.  Many lawyers are oppressed.  The lawyer industry has no hope at all.

Back in January, Chang was detained for 10 days and his lawyer's license was cancelled for what they called suspicion of subverting state power, after he met with some dissidents.  In October, Chang released a video of being tortured during his January detention.  Thereafter, he was placed under house arrest for the second time.  Reporting by Xiong Bin, NTD News.

This year, Germany will finish its term on the United Nations Security Council, and Ambassador Christoph Heusgen plans to retire after 40 years as a diplomat.  On Heusgen's last council meeting, China's Deputy UN Ambassador Geng Shuang gave him a humiliating farewell.  He said, out of the bottom of my heart, good riddance, Ambassador Heusgen.  The Chinese ambassador's comment comes after the German UN envoy asked China to release Canadian citizens Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor.  The two Canadians are currently jailed in China.  Their imprisonment came as retaliation shortly after Canadian police arrested Huawei Technologies Chief Financial Officer Meng Wanzhou.  China's UN ambassador, Geng Shuang, is a former spokesman for China's foreign ministry.  He was one of Beijing's prominent so-called wolf warrior diplomats.  Now we look to another virus in China.  As the pandemic in China is heating up, another deadly virus broke out in Yongzhou City, Hunan Province in southern China.  Chinese media reported over the weekend a woman in the city was diagnosed with the highly lethal H5N6 bird flu, one of the live poultry trading markets closed on the same day.  All other markets of this kind in the same county followed suit on the next day.  but authorities did not explain whether this was connected to the case.  The woman is being treated with a respirator in intensive care in a hospital.  People in close contact with her are being closely monitored.  Animal-to-human transmission of H5N6 bird flu is very rare.  Patients normally show heavy symptoms such as fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, among others.  Its fatality rate is as high as 70 percent, according to the World Health Organization.  There is no human-to-human transmission reported so far.  Australia is in a trade conflict with China, but the price of iron ore, which is Australia's biggest export to China, is soaring to an eight-year high.  NTD's Becky Zhou has the story.

The price of iron ore has increased more than 30 percent since early November, reaching more than $150 per ton on Wednesday.  Australian iron ore has escaped trade restrictions from the Chinese regime.

The Chinese Communist Party initially wanted to use iron ore to coerce Australia.  It seems that the outcome is contrary to what the CCP wanted to see.  The CCP has to spend more money importing it.  This exacerbates the problems of China's economy and comes as a new blow to its GDP.

The Australian government called for a global inquiry into China's handling of the outbreak in April.  In retaliation, China's communist regime has since restricted imports of Australian coal, meat, sugar, barley, cotton and wine.  But one of Australia's biggest exports to China, iron ore, escaped retaliation.  China sources 80% of its iron ore from other countries, of which more than 60% comes from Australia.  Australia is the world's leading exporter of iron.  Increased earnings from mining exports have helped to support the Australian economy during the pandemic.  Australia's national broadcaster ABC says the price of iron ore is rising due to higher demand in China.  lower supply from Brazil and trading in financial markets.  As a result, steel companies in China have to pay more to import iron ore.  The vice chairman of the Iron and Steel Association of China said the price increase went beyond expectations.  The steel industry is likely to suffer more losses.  Analyst at Standard & Porter says high iron ore price will continue into the first quarter of the next year.  Reporting by Becky Zhou, NTD News.

Now a look to the CCP's infiltration of foreign students in China.  Documents obtained by NTD's sister company, The Epoch Times, show socialist ideology and Beijing's narratives are part of the curricula not only for Chinese students, but also for foreign students from Southeast and Central Asia.  It's closely related to Beijing's Belt and Road Initiative.  Yunnan Mingzhu University in southwestern China's Kunming City is one of the schools offering this program.  The university explained its intention is to train talents for the Belt and Road Initiative operating in five southwestern Asian countries, like Cambodia, Laos, Burma, Thailand and Vietnam.  The Mekong River runs through all these countries, so the project is called Mekong Corporation Project.  In these Mekong project countries, the CCP is promoting the Belt and Road Initiative with great effort.  The initiative is a global CCP project to build infrastructure, mainly in developing countries in Asia and Africa, as well as in some Western countries such as Australia and Italy.  It has placed some countries under massive debt.  This was used by the CCP to put economic pressure on governments so they agree with Beijing's agenda.  Leaked documents show foreign students participating in this Mekong project will study China's policies in political and economic areas.  Classes would include theory and practice of socialism with Chinese characteristics, and research on the CCP's innovative theory.  Classes about Chinese culture have little to do with traditional Chinese culture, but aim to promote Beijing's narratives on its domestic and foreign policy.  As for the financial aspect, the Mekong Talent Project applied for $1 million from the CCP.  It covers the costs of training 100 university students, 100 government officials, and 3,000 workers from the countries.  Another translator training program was allocated a $760,000 budget for the year 2018.  It covers the costs of training 100 translators from five countries.  Besides, the Yunnan Police College has promoted the Belt and Road Initiative through a police master's degree for foreign police officers from more than 17 countries, such as Afghanistan, Argentina, Pakistan, the Philippines, Vietnam.  China's Ministry of Public Security funds their tuition and living expenses.  Similar programs have also been offered in the universities in northwest China to train students from Central Asian countries that have joined the Belt and Road Initiative.  A university in the region filed an application earlier this year to receive funding.  It wrote, the plans can effectively broaden positive public opinion to support the Belt and Road Initiative in these foreign countries, including eliminating voices of criticism and opposition.  Communist officials allegedly attacked U.S.  diplomats and its own citizens with a new form of weapon.  NTD's Becky Jo has the story.

U.S.  State Department officials have recently told reporters that brain attacks do exist in China.  U.S.  diplomats suffered significant injuries in a series of attacks in 2017 that seemed to target their brains.  The symptoms include fatigue, dizziness, hearing loss, balance problems and trouble concentrating, among others.  The National Academy of Sciences found that directed microwave radiation.  It's a likely cause of illnesses among American diplomats in China.  73 Chinese victims of electromagnetic attacks filed complaints to authorities in Beijing in 2017.  Mr.  Zhong, a member of the anti-brain attack organization, said there were much more victims in China, but the regime ignored their cases and regarded them as mentally ill.  Since June of last year, the Chinese regime have allegedly attacked two sisters with electromagnetic waves.  Chi Guixia and Chi Guimin live in a shared home in Harbin of China.  U.S.-based Irene Wang, daughter of Chi Guixia, says officials allegedly emitted electromagnetic waves towards them at home, hurting their brains.  Members of the National Security Agency drive a car that emanates signals and electromagnetic waves.  These signals target my mother and aunt because they practice Falun Gong.  They were persecuted before for their faith.  Falun Gong, also known as Falun Dafa, is a spiritual practice in the Buddhist tradition that espouses the core tenets of truthfulness, compassion and tolerance.  The regime has been persecuting Falun Gong practitioners since 1999.  Their heads hurt as if someone is holding their skull.  They can't sleep.  It's very painful even when they put their heads on pillows.  It's very hard for them to fall asleep.

The sisters also had difficulty breathing.  Once they moved to the homes of their relatives, the predicament stopped right away.  But officials continued to follow and monitor the sisters round the clock no matter where they went.  Their relatives fell prey to the stalking as well.  The sisters had no choice but to move back to avoid creating trouble for their relatives.  They reported these incidents to local police but to no avail.  The Chinese Communist Party persecute people in an invisible manner.  I hope that more people will be aware of these attacks one day.  If any victims ask for your help, at least you know these incidents did occur.  Reporting by Becky Zhou, NTD News.

A Hong Kong protester who was shot by police last year is in exile.  An advocacy group revealed the news and said he is in an undisclosed location.  19-year-old Sun Chi-kin was shot and wounded during a pro-democracy protest.  He was the first of two people police shot during a month-long series of protests.  Sun did not show up for a court hearing on Tuesday.  Pro-democracy group Friends of Hong Kong revealed in a statement that he and some fellow protesters left the city.  The group said Sun and some friends were unable to obtain asylum at the local U.S.  consulate.  The U.S.  consulate stated its policy that asylum could only be requested upon arrival on American soil.  And that's all for today's China In Focus.  But before you go, we have an announcement.  There will not be any shows for Christmas Eve or Christmas Day.  Merry Christmas and to everyone else, happy holidays.  Thanks for watching and see you next time.
